		7-C-3: Vocabulary Review
		
									March 4, 2012
						

	

		
		7-C-3: Vocabulary Review




Bell Curve

Image via Wikipedia



The normal distribution associated with most sets of real-world data. Due to the shape of this distribution, it is also famously called the “bell curve.”
http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=bell+curve&a=*C.bell+curve-_*MathWorld-



Median

The statistical median, which is an order statistic that gives the “middle” value of a sample.
http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=median&a=*C.median-_*MathWorld-&f2=%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D&f=MedianCalculator.list_%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D



Mode

The most common value obtained in a set of observations. For example, for a data set (3, 7, 3, 9, 9, 3, 5, 1, 8, 5), the unique mode is 3. Similarly, for a data set (2, 4, 9, 6, 4, 6, 6, 2, 8, 2), there are two modes: 2 and 6. A distribution with a single mode is said to be unimodal. A distribution with more than one mode is said to be bimodal, trimodal, etc., or in general, multimodal.
http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=mode&a=*C.mode-_*MathWorld-



Range

The difference between the minimum and the maximum values of a data set.
http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=range&a=*C.range-_*MathWorld-



Standard Deviation

A statistic that measures how spread out a set of data is.  It is defined as the square root of the variance.
http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=standard+deviation&a=*C.standard+deviation-_*MathWorld-&f2=%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D&f=StandardDeviationCalculator.list_%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D&a=*FP.StandardDeviationCalculator.Form-_Pop

		6-C-2 Vocabulary Review
		
									February 25, 2012
						

	

		
		6-C-2





Term



Informal Definition



Formal Definition




Tree Diagram






A diagram that displays the various combinations of elements.
A diagram that shows all of the
possible outcomes of an event.

http://www.webquest.hawaii.edu

/kahihi/mathdictionary/T/

treediagram.php

 








Outcomes
The result of a game of chance.
A single, specific possible result
of an experiment.

http://www.mathwords.com

/o/outcome.htm

 








Fundamental Counting Principle
A process to determine the number of outcomes by multiplying the various options available.
The Counting Principle is used to
find the number of possible

outcomes.  It states that if an

event has m possible outcomes

and another independent event

has n possible outcomes, then

there are mn possible outcomes

for the two events together.

http://www.icoachmath.com

/math_dictionary/

Counting_Principle.html

 








Pascal’s Triangle


Image via Wikipedia


A triangular display of numbers where two number on the preceding row are added together to determine the number immediately below.  This triangle contains numerous patterns within it, including the ability to determine combinations and probability.
A triangular array of binomial
coefficients that can visually

illustrate several of their

properties.

http://www.wolframalpha.com

/input/?i=pascal%27s+triangle&a=

*C.pascal%27s+triangle-_*MathWorld-

 








Dependent Event
An event that is affected by another event.
If the outcome of one event
affects the outcome of another,

then the events are said to be

dependent events.

http://www.icoachmath.com

/math_dictionary/Dependent_Events.html

		5-C-3 – Module 5 Vocabulary
		
									February 17, 2012
						

	

		
		



Term



Informal Definition



Formal Definition




Tessellation
A mosaic made up of identical shaped figures that fit together in such a way as to completely tile a plane with no spaces left open.
A tiling of regular polygons (in two dimensions), polyhedra (three dimensions), or polytopes (n dimensions) is called a tessellation.The breaking up of self-intersecting polygons into simple polygons is also called tessellation, or more properly, polygon tessellation.There are exactly three regular tessellations composed of regular polygons symmetrically tiling the plane.
Tessellations of the plane by two or more convex regular polygons such that the same polygons in the same order surround each polygon vertex are called semi-regular tessellations, or sometimes Archimedean tessellations. In the plane, there are eight such tessellations. . . .

http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=+tessellation



Polygon
A shape made up of three or more line segments.  Polygons may be convex or concave.
A two-dimensional figure that consists of a collection of line segments, joined at their ends. A polygon can be defined (as illustrated above) as a geometric object (open curly double quote) consisting of a number of points (called vertices) and an equal number of line segments (called sides), namely a cyclically ordered set of points in a plane, with no three successive points collinear, together with the line segments joining consecutive pairs of the points.http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=+polygon&a=*C.polygon-_*MathWorld-


Regular Polygon
 

A shape made up of three or more line segments that all have the same measure.  All regular polygons are convex.
A polygon in which the sides are all the same length and the angles all have the same measure. A regular polygon is an n-sided polygon in which the sides are all the same length and are symmetrically placed about a common center (i.e., the polygon is both equiangular and equilateral).http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=regular+polygon&a=*C.regular+polygon-_*MathWorld-


Edge
The line segment where two different polygonal faces of a polyhedron intersect.
A line segment where two faces of a polyhedron meet.http://www.mathematicsdictionary.com/math-vocabulary.htm


Vertex      (pl. vertices)
The intersection point of two edges of a polyhedron or the intersection point of two sides of a polygon.
A point shared by three or more sides of a solid figure. A point at which the two rays of an angle meet or the intersection point of two sides of a plane figure.http://www.mathematicsdictionary.com/math-vocabulary.htm

		5-B-1: Creating and Identifying Mathematical Mosaics
		
									February 16, 2012
						

	

		
		5-B-1:  Creating and Identifying Mathematical Mosaics

Mathematical Mosaic 1:

This mosaic is on the wall of the bathroom over the tub.  The mosaic is made up of squares and isosceles right triangles.  The two legs of the isosceles right triangles are the same length as the sides of the square.  The measure of the interior angles of the squares are all 90°.  The measures of the interior angles of the isosceles right triangles are 90°, 45°, and 45°.



Mathematical Mosaic 2:

The mosaic on the floor of my bathroom is made up of octagons with squares in between.  The sides of the squares are the same length as the side of the regular octagons.  The measure of the interior angles of the squares are all 90°.  The measure of the interior angles of the regular octagon are all 135°.

I think that students become more involved in mathematics every time they are asked to recognize the mathematics all around them.  The more connections they can make between what we do in class and what we see all around us, the more likely they are to develop a deep understanding of the mathematics we are teaching.

To ensure that students have learned, I would want them to design a mathematical mosaic using regular polygons.  I would ask my students to explain why the polygons they chose to use are appropriate for this lesson.  Students would be requested to determine the sum of the measures of the angles surrounding a point where all of the polygons in their mosaic meet in at least two different ways.  Students could be asked to recreate their mosaic using different polygons, but with the same basic design, e.g., replacing a hexagon with two trapezoids or 6 equilateral triangles.

		4-C-3 – Sharing Web Resources
		
									February 13, 2012
						

	

		
		http://mathwire.com/archives/algebra.html

This link contained numerous links to activities and articles about teaching functions to elementary students.  This site also had numerous templates for teaching functions.  These templates would be able to be used in other similar activities that you may already use.

http://www.nsa.gov/academia/_files/collected_learning/elementary/patterns/magic_function_machine.pdf

This link goes to a set of related lessons teaching functions to 3rd and 4th grade students.  It includes lessons, templates, and assessment checklists.  It provides a nice elementary level approach to introducing functions, and function tables to elementary students.

http://www.cehd.umn.edu/rationalnumberproject/01_1.html

This is a link to an article from NCTM’s Mathematics Teaching In the Middle School.  The article, Using Models to Build Middle-Grade Students’ Understanding of Functions, gives examples of how to introduce the idea of functions and help students to master the content.  The link takes you to a page of the Rational Number Project.

http://mason.gmu.edu/~jsuh4/impact/PFAEntire.pdf

The link goes to a handout for professional development of elementary teachers compiled by the Virginia Department of Education.  The training covered patterns, functions, and algebra.  The handout includes a table of contents if you want to go directly to the section on functions.

		4-B-2 Glossary
		
									February 12, 2012
						

	

		
		





Term



Informal Definitiion



Formal Definition




Base Number
The number in a power that represents the factor that is raised to a power.
a in the expression a^x. For example, 2 is the base in 2^3.http://www.mathwords.com/b/base_exponential.htm


Exponent
The number in a power that identifies the number of factors of the base number.
An exponent is the power p in an expression of the form a^p. The process of performing the operation of raising a base to a given power is known as exponentiation.http://mathworld.wolfram.com/search/?query=exponent&x=0&y=0


Function

Image via Wikipedia


A relationship between two numbers – an input and an output.  For a relation to be a function, for every input value there must be exactly one output value.
A function is a special relationship between values: Each of its input values gives back exactly one output value. A function relates each element of a set with exactly one element of another set (possibly the same set).http://www.mathsisfun.com/definitions/function.html


Input Value
In a function, it is the independent value.
The number or value that is entered, for example, into a function machine. The number that goes into the machine is the input.http://www.shodor.org/interactivate/dictionary/


Output Value
In a function, it is the dependent value.
The number or value that comes out from a process. For example, in a function machine, a number goes in, something is done to it, and the resulting number is the outputhttp://www.shodor.org/interactivate/dictionary/

		3-C-2 Math Glossary
		
									February 5, 2012
						

	

		
		
Math Glossary

 

The formal definitions have come from www.wolframalpha.com , www.nctm.org , and http://mathforum.org/dr.math/.   The informal definitions have come from prior knowledge.

 





Term



Informal Definition



Formal Definition




Logic
The process for determining a solution to a problem through the use of single steps, each one factually supported by information contained in the original problem or from conclusions reached in prior steps.
The formal mathematical study of the methods, structure, and validity of mathematical deduction and proof.  www.wolframalpha.com


Number Sense
 

The ability of an individual to determine whether a solution is reasonable and the ability to determine the manner in which numbers may be combined in order to reach a reasonable solution.
[The ability] to naturally decompose numbers, use particular numbers as referents, solve problems using the relationships among operations and knowledge about the base-ten system, estimate a reasonable result for a problem, and have a disposition to make sense of numbers, problems, and results. Principles and Standards for School Mathematics,  Standards Overview, http://www.nctm.org/standards/content.aspx?id=26859


Operations







The method for manipulating and combining numbers in certain ways, most commonly: addition, subtraction, multiplication, division.
An operation works to change numbers. (The word operate comes from Latin operari, “to work.”) There are six operations in arithmetic that “work on” numbers: addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, raising to powers, and taking roots. http://mathforum.org/dr.math/

		3-B-3 Marbles in the MatchBox
		
									February 4, 2012
						

	

		
		3-B-3 – Marbles in the Matchbox

1.            Looking at the squares on which the pennies were placed on each board, you can see that when pennies are placed on the same color, A wins, and when they are placed on different colors, B wins.

2.              Because I am reaching my conclusion on eight examples, rather than trying every possibility, I am using inductive reasoning to conclude that this pattern will continue.

3.              The eight examples do not prove that my conclusion is correct.  Instead, they simply suggest that my conclusion may be correct.

4.              The board is set up with squares of two alternating colors.  Thus, if two squares must share a common side, the colors of those two squares must be different.

5.              If player B places seven paper clips, covering fourteen squares, there must be seven white and seven brown squares.

6.              If player A places the pennies on two white squares, the remaining fourteen squares would be composed of six white and eight brown squares.

7.              If player A places the pennies on two brown squares, the remaining fourteen squares would be composed of six brown and eight white squares.

8.              If player A places the pennies on one white square and one brown square, the remaining fourteen squares would be composed of seven brown squares and seven white squares.

9.              Through the use of inductive reasoning, I conclude that my answer to question one is correct for every possible game.

10.           In the marbles and matchbox puzzle, there are three matchboxes, each containing two marbles.  One of the boxes had a white and a red marble, one had two red marbles, and one had two white marbles.  All three boxes are labeled, but none of the boxes are labeled correctly.

Thus, if you opened the box labeled “2 red”, and saw a red marble, the other marble would have to be white.  You know that the box labeled “2 red” has to contain either two white marbles or a red and a white marble.  The only box with a red marble in it would be the one with one white and one red.

11.           If you opened the box labeled “2 red”, and saw a white marble, the other marble could be red or white.  You know that the box labeled “2 red” has to contain either two white marbles or a red and a white marble.  If you opened the box containing two white marbles, the other marble would be white.  If you opened the box with one marble of each color, the other marble would be red.

12.           If you opened the box labeled “2 white”, and saw a white marble, the other marble has to be red.  You know that the box labeled “2 white” has to contain either two red marbles or a red and a white marble.  Because you saw a white marble, it can only be the box containing both a red and a white marble.

13.           If you opened the box labeled “2 white”, and saw a red marble, the other marble could be either red or white.  You know that the box labeled “2 white” has to contain either two red marbles or a red and a white marble.  Thus, finding a red marble does not help determine the outcome because it could be either the box with two red marbles or the box with both a red and a white marble.

14.           If you opened the box labeled “1 red, 1 white”, and saw a red marble, the other marble has to be red.  You know that the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” has to contain either two red marbles or two white marbles.  Because you saw a red marble, it can only be the box containing two red marbles.

15.           If you opened the box labeled “1 red, 1 white”, and saw a white marble, the other marble has to be white.  You know that the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” has to contain either two red marbles or two white marbles.  Because you saw a white marble, it can only be the box containing two white marbles.

16.           The matchbox with one marble of each color is the best matchbox to choose in order to maximize your chances of guessing correctly by looking at one marble.  With this box, once you know the color of one marble, you automatically know the color of the other marble.

17.           If you see a red marble when you open the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” (and therefore containing two marbles of the same color), you know that the other marble has to be red.

18.           If you see a red marble when you open the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” (and therefore containing two marbles of the same color), you know that box must contain two red marbles.  You also know that the marbles in the box labeled “2 white” (and therefore containing either two red marbles or one red and one white), cannot be both red because those were in the “1 red, 1 white” box.  As a result, you know that the box labeled “2 white” must contain one marble of each color.

19.           If you see a red marble when you open the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” (and therefore containing two marbles of the same color), you know that box must contain two red marbles.  You also know that the marbles in the box labeled “2 white” (and therefore containing either two red marbles or one red and one white), cannot be both red because those were in the “1 red, 1 white” box.  As a result, you know that the box labeled “2 white” must contain one marble of each color.  Because there are only three choices (RW, WW, RR)  and the first two boxes have to be RR, and RW, the last box labeled “2 red” must contain two white marbles.  See below.





Label:



2 red



2 white



1 red and 1 white










Possibility 1:

WR



RR



WW




Possibility 2:

WW



WR



RR

		2-C-2 Glossary
		
									January 28, 2012
						

	

		
		Math Glossary

 

The formal definitions have come from www.wolframalpha.com.  The informal definitions have come from prior knowledge.





Term



Informal Definition



Formal Definition




Absolute Value
The distance from a number to the origin on a number line.  The absolute value of a number is always positive.
The distance of a number from the origin.   Absolute value is an example of a norm.


Rational Numbers

Image via Wikipedia


Real numbers that can be written as a common fraction, with integers for both the numerator and denominator.
A real number that can be written as a quotient of two integers.


Irrational Numbers
Real numbers that cannot be written as a fraction with integers for the numerator and denominator.
A number that cannot be written as a fraction.  Irrational numbers have decimal expansions that neither terminate nor become periodic.

		Welcome!
		
									
						

	

		
		Hello.  My name is Val and I am teach math at a middle school in Michigan.  By the time this course ends, I hope to learn new ways to engage my students, but more importantly, I would like to learn ways of taking students below grade level and help them to become more fluent and capable in math.  Due to limited time and resources, I want to be able to maximize my time on task to help them as much as I can during our year together.

<div class="post-350 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-glossary category-thinking-mathematically" id="post-350">
	<div class="main-title">
		<h3><a href="https://valmath.wordpress.com/2012/03/04/7-c-3-vocabulary-review/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">7-C-3: Vocabulary Review</a></h3>
		<div class="post-date">
									<span>March 4, 2012</span>
						</div>

	</div>

		<div class="entry">
		<p>7-C-3: Vocabulary Review</p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="91">Bell Curve
<p></p>
<div style="width: 85px" class="wp-caption alignleft"><a href="http://commons.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Standard_deviation_diagram.svg" target="_blank"><img class="zemanta-img-inserted zemanta-img-configured" title="English: Normal distribution curve that illust..." src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://i0.wp.com/upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Standard_deviation_diagram.svg/300px-Standard_deviation_diagram.svg.png" alt="English: Normal distribution curve that illust..." width="75" height="38"></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Image via Wikipedia</p>
</div>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="12"></td>
<td valign="top" width="340">The normal distribution associated with most sets of real-world data. Due to the shape of this distribution, it is also famously called the “bell curve.”
<p><a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=bell+curve&a=*C.bell+curve-_*MathWorld-" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=bell+curve&a=*C.bell+curve-_*MathWorld-</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="91">Median</td>
<td valign="top" width="12"></td>
<td valign="top" width="340">The statistical median, which is an order statistic that gives the “middle” value of a sample.
<p><a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=median&a=*C.median-_*MathWorld-&f2=%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D&f=MedianCalculator.list_%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=median&a=*C.median-_*MathWorld-&f2=%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D&f=MedianCalculator.list_%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="91">Mode</td>
<td valign="top" width="12"></td>
<td valign="top" width="340">The most common value obtained in a set of observations. For example, for a data set (3, 7, 3, 9, 9, 3, 5, 1, 8, 5), the unique mode is 3. Similarly, for a data set (2, 4, 9, 6, 4, 6, 6, 2, 8, 2), there are two modes: 2 and 6. A distribution with a single mode is said to be unimodal. A distribution with more than one mode is said to be bimodal, trimodal, etc., or in general, multimodal.
<p><a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=mode&a=*C.mode-_*MathWorld-" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=mode&a=*C.mode-_*MathWorld-</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="91">Range</td>
<td valign="top" width="12"></td>
<td valign="top" width="340">The difference between the minimum and the maximum values of a data set.
<p><a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=range&a=*C.range-_*MathWorld-" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=range&a=*C.range-_*MathWorld-</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="91">Standard Deviation</td>
<td valign="top" width="12"></td>
<td valign="top" width="340">A statistic that measures how spread out a set of data is.  It is defined as the square root of the variance.
<p><a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=standard+deviation&a" target="_blank">http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=standard+deviation&a</a>=*C.standard+deviation-_*MathWorld-&f2=%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D&f=StandardDeviationCalculator.list_%7B1%2C2%2C-2%2C4%2C-3%7D&a=*FP.StandardDeviationCalculator.Form-_Pop</p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

<td valign="top" width="203">The Counting Principle is used to

<tr>

<tr>

<div class="post-116 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-glossary category-thinking-mathematically" id="post-116">
	<div class="main-title">
		<h3><a href="https://valmath.wordpress.com/2012/02/17/5-c-3-module-5-vocabulary/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">5-C-3 – Module 5 Vocabulary</a></h3>
		<div class="post-date">

		<div class="entry">
		<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="153">
<p align="center"><strong>Term</strong><strong></strong></p>

</td>
<td valign="top" width="158">
<p align="center"><strong>Informal Definition</strong><strong></strong></p>

</td>
<td valign="top" width="189">
<p align="center"><strong>Formal Definition</strong><strong></strong></p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="153">Tessellation<a href="http://commons.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:P3_hull.png" target="_blank"><img class="zemanta-img-inserted zemanta-img-configured  alignleft" title="English: Tessellation Deutsch: Parkettierung" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://i0.wp.com/upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/P3_hull.png/300px-P3_hull.png" alt="English: Tessellation Deutsch: Parkettierung" width="108" height="108"></a></td>
<td valign="top" width="158">A mosaic made up of identical shaped figures that fit together in such a way as to completely tile a plane with no spaces left open.</td>
<td valign="top" width="189">A tiling of regular polygons (in two dimensions), polyhedra (three dimensions), or polytopes (n dimensions) is called a tessellation.The breaking up of self-intersecting polygons into simple polygons is also called tessellation, or more properly, polygon tessellation.There are exactly three regular tessellations composed of regular polygons symmetrically tiling the plane.
<p>Tessellations of the plane by two or more convex regular polygons such that the same polygons in the same order surround each polygon vertex are called semi-regular tessellations, or sometimes Archimedean tessellations. In the plane, there are eight such tessellations. . . .</p>

<p><a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=+tessellation" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=+tessellation</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="153">Polygon</td>
<td valign="top" width="158">A shape made up of three or more line segments.  Polygons may be convex or concave.</td>
<td valign="top" width="189">A two-dimensional figure that consists of a collection of line segments, joined at their ends. A polygon can be defined (as illustrated above) as a geometric object (open curly double quote) consisting of a number of points (called vertices) and an equal number of line segments (called sides), namely a cyclically ordered set of points in a plane, with no three successive points collinear, together with the line segments joining consecutive pairs of the points.<a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=+polygon&a=*C.polygon-_*MathWorld-" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=+polygon&a=*C.polygon-_*MathWorld-</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="153">Regular Polygon<a href="http://commons.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hexagon_Reflections.png" target="_blank"><img class="zemanta-img-inserted zemanta-img-configured alignleft" title="The six reflection symmetries of a regular hex..." src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://i0.wp.com/upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Hexagon_Reflections.png/300px-Hexagon_Reflections.png" alt="The six reflection symmetries of a regular hex..." width="65" height="65"></a>
<p> </p>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="158">A shape made up of three or more line segments that all have the same measure.  All regular polygons are convex.</td>
<td valign="top" width="189">A polygon in which the sides are all the same length and the angles all have the same measure. A regular polygon is an n-sided polygon in which the sides are all the same length and are symmetrically placed about a common center (i.e., the polygon is both equiangular and equilateral).<a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=regular+polygon&a=*C.regular+polygon-_*MathWorld-" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=regular+polygon&a=*C.regular+polygon-_*MathWorld-</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="153">Edge</td>
<td valign="top" width="158">The line segment where two different polygonal faces of a polyhedron intersect.</td>
<td valign="top" width="189">A line segment where two faces of a polyhedron meet.<a href="http://www.mathematicsdictionary.com/math-vocabulary.htm" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.mathematicsdictionary.com/math-vocabulary.htm</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="153">Vertex      (pl. vertices)</td>
<td valign="top" width="158">The intersection point of two edges of a polyhedron or the intersection point of two sides of a polygon.</td>
<td valign="top" width="189">A point shared by three or more sides of a solid figure. A point at which the two rays of an angle meet or the intersection point of two sides of a plane figure.<a href="http://www.mathematicsdictionary.com/math-vocabulary.htm" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">http://www.mathematicsdictionary.com/math-vocabulary.htm</a></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

<div class="post-81 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-thinking-mathematically" id="post-81">
	<div class="main-title">
		<h3><a href="https://valmath.wordpress.com/2012/02/16/5-b-1/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">5-B-1: Creating and Identifying Mathematical Mosaics</a></h3>
		<div class="post-date">
									<span>February 16, 2012</span>
						</div>

	</div>

		<div class="entry">
		<p><strong>5-B-1<em>:  </em>Creating and Identifying Mathematical Mosaics</strong></p>

<p><strong>Mathematical Mosaic 1:</strong></p>

<p>This mosaic is on the wall of the bathroom over the tub.  The mosaic is made up of squares and isosceles right triangles.  The two legs of the isosceles right triangles are the same length as the sides of the square.  The measure of the interior angles of the squares are all 90°.  The measures of the interior angles of the isosceles right triangles are 90°, 45°, and 45°.</p>

<p><img data-attachment-id="82" data-permalink="https://valmath.wordpress.com/2012/02/16/5-b-1/mosaic/" data-orig-file="https://valmath.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/mosaic.jpg" data-orig-size="2048,1536" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta='{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"VS660","caption":"","created_timestamp":"1329409629","copyright":"","focal_length":"4.31","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":""}' data-image-title="mosaic" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://valmath.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/mosaic.jpg?w=300" data-large-file="https://valmath.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/mosaic.jpg?w=540" class="wp-image-82 alignnone" title="mosaic" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://valmath.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/mosaic.jpg?w=108&h=81" alt="" width="108" height="81" srcset="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://valmath.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/mosaic.jpg?w=108 108w, https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url= https://valmath.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/mosaic.jpg?w=216 216w, https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url= https://valmath.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/mosaic.jpg?w=150 150w" sizes="(max-width: 108px) 100vw, 108px"></p>

<p><strong>Mathematical Mosaic 2:</strong></p>

<p>The mosaic on the floor of my bathroom is made up of octagons with squares in between.  The sides of the squares are the same length as the side of the regular octagons.  The measure of the interior angles of the squares are all 90<em>°</em>.  The measure of the interior angles of the regular octagon are all 135°.</p>

<p>I think that students become more involved in mathematics every time they are asked to recognize the mathematics all around them.  The more connections they can make between what we do in class and what we see all around us, the more likely they are to develop a deep understanding of the mathematics we are teaching.</p>

<p>To ensure that students have learned, I would want them to design a mathematical mosaic using regular polygons.  I would ask my students to explain why the polygons they chose to use are appropriate for this lesson.  Students would be requested to determine the sum of the measures of the angles surrounding a point where all of the polygons in their mosaic meet in at least two different ways.  Students could be asked to recreate their mosaic using different polygons, but with the same basic design, e.g., replacing a hexagon with two trapezoids or 6 equilateral triangles.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.nsa.gov/academia/_files/collected_learning/elementary/patterns/magic_function_machine.pdf" target="_blank">http://www.nsa.gov/academia/_files/collected_learning/elementary/patterns/magic_function_machine.pdf</a></p>

<p>This link goes to a set of related lessons teaching functions to 3<sup>rd</sup> and 4<sup>th</sup> grade students.  It includes lessons, templates, and assessment checklists.  It provides a nice elementary level approach to introducing functions, and function tables to elementary students.</p>

The link takes you to a page of the Rational Number Project.</p>

<p><a href="http://mason.gmu.edu/~jsuh4/impact/PFAEntire.pdf" target="_blank">http://mason.gmu.edu/~jsuh4/impact/PFAEntire.pdf</a></p>

<div class="post-22 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-thinking-mathematically" id="post-22">
	<div class="main-title">
		<h3><a href="https://valmath.wordpress.com/2012/02/04/22/" rel="bookmark" target="_blank">3-B-3 Marbles in the MatchBox</a></h3>
		<div class="post-date">
									<span>February 4, 2012</span>
						</div>

	</div>

		<div class="entry">
		<p><strong>3-B-3 – Marbles in the Matchbox</strong></p>

<p>1.            Looking at the squares on which the pennies were placed on each board, you can see that when pennies are placed on the same color, A wins, and when they are placed on different colors, B wins.</p>

<p>2.              Because I am reaching my conclusion on eight examples, rather than trying every possibility, I am using inductive reasoning to conclude that this pattern will continue.</p>

<p>3.              The eight examples do not prove that my conclusion is correct.  Instead, they simply suggest that my conclusion may be correct.</p>

<p>4.              The board is set up with squares of two alternating colors.  Thus, if two squares must share a common side, the colors of those two squares must be different.</p>

<p>5.              If player B places seven paper clips, covering fourteen squares, there must be seven white and seven brown squares.</p>

<p>6.              If player A places the pennies on two white squares, the remaining fourteen squares would be composed of six white and eight brown squares.</p>

<p>7.              If player A places the pennies on two brown squares, the remaining fourteen squares would be composed of six brown and eight white squares.</p>

<p>8.              If player A places the pennies on one white square and one brown square, the remaining fourteen squares would be composed of seven brown squares and seven white squares.</p>

<p>9.              Through the use of inductive reasoning, I conclude that my answer to question one is correct for every possible game.</p>

<p>10.           In the marbles and matchbox puzzle, there are three matchboxes, each containing two marbles.  One of the boxes had a white and a red marble, one had two red marbles, and one had two white marbles.  All three boxes are labeled, but none of the boxes are labeled correctly.</p>

<p>Thus, if you opened the box labeled “2 red”, and saw a red marble, the other marble would have to be white.  You know that the box labeled “2 red” has to contain either two white marbles or a red and a white marble.  The only box with a red marble in it would be the one with one white and one red.</p>

<p>11.           If you opened the box labeled “2 red”, and saw a white marble, the other marble could be red or white.  You know that the box labeled “2 red” has to contain either two white marbles or a red and a white marble.  If you opened the box containing two white marbles, the other marble would be white.  If you opened the box with one marble of each color, the other marble would be red.</p>

<p>12.           If you opened the box labeled “2 white”, and saw a white marble, the other marble has to be red.  You know that the box labeled “2 white” has to contain either two red marbles or a red and a white marble.  Because you saw a white marble, it can only be the box containing both a red and a white marble.</p>

<p>13.           If you opened the box labeled “2 white”, and saw a red marble, the other marble could be either red or white.  You know that the box labeled “2 white” has to contain either two red marbles or a red and a white marble.  Thus, finding a red marble does not help determine the outcome because it could be either the box with two red marbles or the box with both a red and a white marble.</p>

<p>14.           If you opened the box labeled “1 red, 1 white”, and saw a red marble, the other marble has to be red.  You know that the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” has to contain either two red marbles or two white marbles.  Because you saw a red marble, it can only be the box containing two red marbles.</p>

<p>15.           If you opened the box labeled “1 red, 1 white”, and saw a white marble, the other marble has to be white.  You know that the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” has to contain either two red marbles or two white marbles.  Because you saw a white marble, it can only be the box containing two white marbles.</p>

<p>16.           The matchbox with one marble of each color is the best matchbox to choose in order to maximize your chances of guessing correctly by looking at one marble.  With this box, once you know the color of one marble, you automatically know the color of the other marble.</p>

<p>17.           If you see a red marble when you open the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” (and therefore containing two marbles of the same color), you know that the other marble has to be red.</p>

<p>18.           If you see a red marble when you open the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” (and therefore containing two marbles of the same color), you know that box must contain two red marbles.  You also know that the marbles in the box labeled “2 white” (and therefore containing either two red marbles or one red and one white), cannot be both red because those were in the “1 red, 1 white” box.  As a result, you know that the box labeled “2 white” must contain one marble of each color.</p>

<p>19.           If you see a red marble when you open the box labeled “1 red, 1 white” (and therefore containing two marbles of the same color), you know that box must contain two red marbles.  You also know that the marbles in the box labeled “2 white” (and therefore containing either two red marbles or one red and one white), cannot be both red because those were in the “1 red, 1 white” box.  As a result, you know that the box labeled “2 white” must contain one marble of each color.  Because there are only three choices (RW, WW, RR)  and the first two boxes have to be RR, and RW, the last box labeled “2 red” must contain two white marbles.  See below.</p>

		<p><strong>Math Glossary</strong></p>

<p><strong> </strong></p>

<p>The formal definitions have come from <a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com" target="_blank">www.wolframalpha.com</a>.  The informal definitions have come from prior knowledge.</p>

<table border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">

<p align="center"><strong>Term</strong></p>

</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="148">Absolute Value</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">The distance from a number to the origin on a number line.  The absolute value of a number is always positive.</td>
<td style="text-align:left;" valign="top" width="148">The distance of a number from the origin.   Absolute value is an example of a norm.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="148">Rational Numbers
<p></p>
<div style="width: 118px" class="wp-caption alignleft"><a href="http://commons.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Subsets.png" target="_blank"><img class="zemanta-img-inserted zemanta-img-configured " title="English: Note: The irrational and rational num..." src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://i0.wp.com/upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Subsets.png/300px-Subsets.png" alt="English: Note: The irrational and rational num..." width="108" height="89"></a><p class="wp-caption-text">Image via Wikipedia</p>
</div>
</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">Real numbers that can be written as a common fraction, with integers for both the numerator and denominator.</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">A real number that can be written as a quotient of two integers.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="148">Irrational Numbers</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">Real numbers that cannot be written as a fraction with integers for the numerator and denominator.</td>
<td valign="top" width="148">A number that cannot be written as a fraction.  Irrational numbers have decimal expansions that neither terminate nor become periodic.</td>
</tr>

<div class="post-1 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-thinking-mathematically" id="post-1">
